text: Wondering if there is any stomach for creating a light-weight method-stubs only package for stats and ml. For example, MLJBase used to extend `fit` and `predict`  from `StatsBase` but the demand for a light-weight base package (`MJLModelInterface`) meant we no longer do so. I’ve bumping up against this again as I try to separate out a metrics package from MLJBase because metrics share a bunch of traits with models (for example `prediction_type` - probabilistic or deterministic). The new StatisticalMeasures package ought not to depend on any of our machine learning model code, but without introducing a third package for the trait stubs I’m stuck. I could create one but it seems the more sensible thing would to get buy-in from StatsBase, and other packages. Thoughts anyone? (I know there is MLBase, but this is more than method stubs).

I have been coming around to the idea that many different `fit` methods should exist in different namespaces.
Because they have different semantics.

Like SkLearn.jl's fit takes observations as rows.
Models.jl's fit takes observations as columns, and takes tuples of matrixes as collections of observations to be given to submodels
MLJ's... 

and if these are all distinct methods then a package could Implement all of them.

text: <@UMY1LV01G> You can learn about the MLJ API for metrics from here: <https://alan-turing-institute.github.io/MLJ.jl/dev/performance_measures/> Discussion re improvements and additions mostly live here: <https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/MLJBase.jl/issues/299> . You will see that our metrics do have scitype traits; objections/suggestions re current design most welcome at that issue. As far as I know, our API is alone in Julia (and rare more generally) in adopting a uniform interface for probabilistic targets. See this: <https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/MLJ.jl/blob/dev/paper/paper.md#a-unified-approach-to-probabilistic-predictions-and-their-evaluation> which is from our paper <https://joss.theoj.org/papers/10.21105/joss.02704> .
